Rewrite this timeline but set 2000 years prior, with the same style and over-arcing story but in a different time period, and the catalyst for the rapture instead being Jesus's death.

"LORE TIMELINE OF AT HELL'S GATE (REDUX) [[4/13/24]]

## PART 1: "Prelude to the postlude."

# [WWIII]

2034 - In a world shackled by economic strife, political instability, and growing concerns over the climate of the future, tensions rise across the globe, primarily in Eastern Europe, Asia, and the Middle East.

2035 - These tensions later escalate into the war that will, unbeknownst to mankind, end all wars, (at least on Earth).

2037 - WWIII begins, with combat and warfare escalating all over the world, from the snowy fortresses of Alaska to the deserted minefields of the Sahara.

2042 - About 5 years into what seems like will be a never-ending war, North Korea finally makes good on decades of nuclear brinkmanship. Major cities around the world, London, Washington D.C., Tokyo, are all engulfed in a hellish blaze of atomic waste.

2042 - NATO decides to retaliate, launching nuclear missiles on major strategic and population centers of the enemy side as well. Almost halving the human population alive at the time. 

2044 - To add insult to injury, a plague begins developing. with incurable effects and very resilient viruses, there is very little hope for humanity.

2050 - As of 1/1/2050, less than 1/3 of the original population of Earth at its peak in 2038 are still alive. (not counting those dead from natural causes).

2054 - Global resources being strained and very little population leads to the remaining factions and nations of Earth to call a temporary detente in order to get back together and hopefully keep mankind from becoming extinct.

# [In their hopelessness, the spires rose.]

2055 - This period of hopelessness soons marks the beginning of a resurgence in religion, leading mankind to construct "doomspires", towering temples of multi-colored bricks to appease God.

[[There are no further information markers in the records until 2099.]]
 
## PART 2: "What hath God wrought?"

# [Signs of the rapture.]

9/14/2099 - On 16:57:53 UTC precisely, the solar eclipse then occurring over North America heralded the beginning of the end, as the few spectators viewed the day turn to night, the thundering roar of a divine horn was heard across the world, traveling faster than the speed of light.

12/11/2099 - A strange celestial object, unknown to man until its striking of the Earth, splashes down in the middle of the Atlantic, seas turn blood red and toxic. Another trumpet sounds.

# ["7" years of trial.] (2100-2105) !!FIRST CATACLYSM!!

During this period, various cataclysmic events are endowed upon the Earth, with each new disaster, another trumpet sounds.

# [Discovery of the fallibility of the divine.]

7/8/2103 - The remnants of a scientific research camp in Antarctica come across a strange monolithic structure in the freezing wastes, inscripted upon it is the first "revelation", presumed to be from God himself. This sparks debate in society over their God's possible fallibility.

# [Even the brightest light will burn out one day.]

8/27/2105 - Suddenly, without any notification, no previous indication, no fanfare, no cataclysmic event, God vanishes. We are alone.

# [Orphans of the father.] 2105-2117

Now that mankind is truly alone, humanity must fend for survival with the very few resources that are available. Demons and lost angels run rampant on the earth, so there is only one thing we must do-

2110 - The plan for constructing a massive spacecraft in order to transport humanity's remnants is developed, it is called "The Exodus", and will take to the stars in 2117.

2117 - Luckily for man, all goes well, and the remnants of mankind takes to the stars and establishes settlements on the inner planets and some on moons of the outer planets.
 
## PART 3: "Let me play among the stars."

# [The Second Exodus]

2117 - With Earth left an irradiated, apocalypse ravaged ruin, The Exodus departs carrying about 500,000 humans, leaving millions on Earth to fend for themselves.

2118 - The first humans reach the inner planets, Mars, Venus, Mercury, etc...

2127 - The last humans to settle the Solar System arrive at moons of the outer planets.

# [Development of new cultures and religions in the planets and moons (as of 2130)]

Mercury - largely uninhabited, mostly focused on industry and mining.

Venus - Cultural center of the inner planets, vast floating cities consisting of inter-connected zeppelins. This cultural paradise leads them to begin the development of a new religion called "Infernism" (more on that later)

Earth - Virtually abandoned, few settlements are located here, with most suffering in a hell on Earth.

Mars - Less culturally focused but more inhabited than Venus, Mars also develops a religion "Deusvultism (crucifiers)", centered around the idea that God has not abandoned Man, and is just testing their fortitude.

Europa - Underwater cities under the ice caps, military capital of the Solar System.

Titan - Home of the most populated city in the Solar System, and location of the Capitol of mankind.

Uranus and beyond - vastly unpopulated, although plans are being made to create a self-sustaining ark that could travel to the farthest reaches of the Solar System and beyond, possibly into deep space and other star systems.

# [The Third (failed) Exodus]

After departing from Titan in 2134 in hopes of finding habitable locations beyond the known Solar System, scans revealed there were none within thousands of light years, dimming hope for humanity's future if disaster were ever to befall them yet again. It is believed everyone on board died (40,000) after losing contact with the ship in 2178.

## PART 4: "SEA OF OFFAL AND ASHES"

# [A cold war] (2135-2174)

This period marked the first true peace in centuries, after decades of despair, things finally seemed like they would soon be going man's way. But war is one of the grim truths of reality.

# [The twins]

Infernism - Infernism, spawned from the zeppelin-cities of Venus, was a religion centered around worshipping a deity called Baphomet. Founded by a supposedly schizophrenic elder trying to rekindle the flames of hope in a world of despair. The Baphomet that the Infernists worship is unrelated to the Baphomet of the old world, and the name is generally understood to be spouted from the founder's mentally ill mind. The Infernists glorify violence, taking heed from a vision the elder had.

Deusvultism - Similarly, Deusvultism also arose from the need for hope in trying times, but is more grounded in reality. The belief holds central the idea that God has not abandoned humanity, but is just testing them to see if humanity is capable of maintaining fortitude in their belief after straying so far from His light. However, many Deusvultists are also heavily fanatical, in stark contrast to their beliefs.

Both religions hold a reputation of being very violent and fanatical, Infernists as part of their belief system, and Deusvultists as the members personalities.

# [Twin Crusades] (2174-2208) !!SECOND CATACLYSM!!

2174 - After tensions between the Infernists and the Deusvultists start running hot, each faction declares holy war on each other.

[MOST HISTORICAL RECORDS HAVE BEEN LOST DURING THIS TIME PERIOD]

2208 - Both sides are exhausted of resources, and constant war and desolation has lead the inner planets to run dry of resources, this is considered to be the second cataclysm of man, following the first, the rapture, 100 years prior.
 
## PART 5: "Hundred year silence"

# [The long night.] (2208-2264)

2208 - The two factions decide to sign a ceasefire after depletion of inner planet resources, motivation, and morale. Each agree to live in isolation and live as their own entities.

2214 - A massive solar flare renders all electronic devices and tools incapable for use in space, trading stops as well as communication between nations, the period of isolation has begun.

Not much else happens during this time period, aside from a few successions of leaders or natural events.

# [Glorified loneliness.] 2264-2301

After the effects of the solar flare wore off, the populace of humanity decided to stay isolated. The reasons behind this were that they believed they should live a peaceful life for the rest of eternity, or at least until the sun died.

[THERE IS NOTHING ELSE IMPORTANT OF NOTE]

## PART 6: "AT HELL'S GATE"

# [Refugees from beyond.]

In the late 2280s, supposedly hyper-evolved humans, descendants of those that arose to paradise but then were abandoned by God arrive in the solar system through rifts in the space-time fabric. They incorporate with the already established factions.

# [The deity's message]

1/1/2301 - With the final curtain call of man, people dying out, nations crumbling, falling, and dying before the universe's eyes, mankind must prepare for one last performance. A sudden signal originating from Pluto is broadcasted across the Solar System. It's message personalized for anyone that receives it, causing each and every human to believe they are "the chosen one", and must go on an odyssey to pluto in order to gain salvation.

1/1/2301 to 2308 - Many die or fail in the struggle to reach Pluto, it is every man for himself, a frenzy unlike any seen in decades. In this struggle's center is ODYSSEUS {placeholder name}, the protagonist of the game's story.

# [The deity's odyssey] 

Odysseus ventures through the planets, encountering original characters, traversing original locations, and finding secrets and lore snippets. At Pluto, he comes face to face with the deity, this deity takes the form of a colossal, almost dream-like serpent towering over mountains. 

[WILL NEED TO THINK MORE ABOUT THE ENDING] !!THIRD CATACLYSM!!"
label:
"LORE TIMELINE OF ECHOES THROUGH ANTIQUITY (REDUX) [[4/13/24 BC]]

## PART 1: "Shadows before the light."

# [The Great Unrest]

34 BC - An empire, vast and mighty, finds itself at the apex of civilization but teetering on the brink of chaos due to economic downturns, political upheaval, and dire omens of a changing world.

35 BC - These underlying tensions erupt into widespread conflict, setting the stage for a cataclysmic confrontation that, unbeknownst to the ancients, would signal the beginning of the end.

37 BC - The Great Unrest unfolds, a series of brutal conflicts engulfing regions from the frozen north to the vast deserts of the south.

42 BC - Roughly five years into the seemingly endless bloodshed, a coalition of city-states unleashes a devastating sorcery. Major capitals, once the epitome of civilization, are consumed by firestorms and earthquakes unnatural in their ferocity.

42 BC - In retaliation, an alliance of their adversaries conjures equally catastrophic magic, decimating populations, and hurling mankind toward extinction.

44 BC - A scourge, borne of the dark arts and unchecked warfare, begins to spread. With mortality high and cures unknown, humanity's hope wanes.

50 BC - By the dawn of 50 BC, barely a fraction of Earth's peak population remains, the victims of war, plague, and famine.

54 BC - The remnants of humanity, scattered and broken, form uneasy alliances, desperately uniting in an attempt to reclaim some semblance of civilization from the ashes.

# [Desperation gives rise to devotion.]

55 BC - Amidst despair, a revival of old faiths and the birth of new ones leads humanity to erect monumental shrines and temples, seeking divine intervention in their doomed existence.

[[Records then lapse into silence until 99 BC.]]

## PART 2: "Divine dissonance."

# [Omens of the divine reckoning.]

9/14/99 BC - During a rare solar eclipse, a celestial horn resounds across the Earth at dusk, signaling the approach of a reckoning long foretold.

12/11/99 BC - A meteor of unknown origins crashes into the sea, turning waters to blood, a second divine horn echoes, marking the beginning of tribulations.

# ["7" years of calamity.] (100-105 BC) !!FIRST CATACLYSM!!

A series of disasters befalls the Earth, each heralded by another trumpet blast, bringing humanity to its knees.

# [Questioning the infallible.]

7/8/103 BC - In the desolation of what was once a lush land, the discovery of an ancient tablet reveals a message thought to be divine, igniting debates over the nature of the gods.

# [The disappearance of the divine.]

8/27/105 BC - Abruptly, the gods fall silent. No signs, no omens, no further disasters. Humanity is left to fend for itself in a world scarred by its past hubris.

# [Forsaken children.] 105-117 BC

In the silence left by the gods, humanity struggles to survive. Demons and divine relicts roam the Earth, prompting survivors to seek escape.

117 BC - An audacious plan is forged to sail beyond the known seas, seeking new lands in a massive exodus named "The Voyage of the Damned".

117 BC - Miraculously, the remnants of humanity embark on their journey, founding colonies on distant shores and establishing new civilizations.

## PART 3: "Among the stars of sand."

# [The Great Voyage]

117 BC - Humanity departs from their ravaged homelands, a fraction of a once vast population venturing into the unknown.

118 BC - The survivors arrive at foreign lands, each with its challenges and opportunities for a fresh start.

127 BC - The last of the explorers settle distant and isolated regions, charting a new course for human history.

# [Emergence of new beliefs and cultures (as of 130 BC)]

New settlements flourish, each developing unique customs and beliefs, from worship of nature spirits to the veneration of ancestors.

Earth - Once a cradle of civilization, now a forsaken and desolate land, home only to those left behind or choosing to dwell amidst the ruins.

# [The Second Desolation]

A confrontation between newly formed factions, each driven by their interpretation of divine will, ignites. Resources dwindle, and humanities' fragile unity fractures.

## PART 4: "A DREAM OF SHADOWS AND DUST"

# [A silent peace] (165-204 BC)

Following the devastation, a fragile peace emerges. Humanity, scattered across distant lands, endeavors to rebuild amidst the ruins of their former glory.

# [The echo of silence.] 204-249 BC

Isolation defines the centuries, as communities turn inward, their gaze turned away from the stars and the horrors of their past.

## PART 5: "ECHOES OF THE DIVINE"

# [Return of the forgotten.]

In the shadows of history, whispers of those guided by the divine, said to have ascended but now returned, begin to permeate through the civilizations, merging with those who remained.

# [A final message]

1/1/250 BC - The world stands on the brink of oblivion once more as a mysterious proclamation spreads across the lands. Each person is beckoned to journey to a sacred site, believed to offer salvation.

1/1/250 BC to 258 BC - The quest for redemption leads many to their demise, as humanity grapples with its destiny. At the heart of this odyssey is a lone figure, a symbol of hope or despair, facing trials that will shape the future of mankind.

# [The odyssey of divinity]

This last champion's journey through ancient lands, encountering forgotten gods and unraveling the threads of fate, leads them to the ultimate confrontation with divinity, in a form both awe-inspiring and terrifying.

[WILL REQUIRE FURTHER REFINEMENT] !!THIRD CATACLYSM!!"

12/11/2099 - A strange celestial object, unknown to man until its striking of the Earth, splashes down in the middle of the Atlantic, seas turn blood red and toxic. Another trumpet sounds.

# ["7" years of trial.] (2100-2105) !!FIRST CATACLYSM!!

During this period, various cataclysmic events are endowed upon the Earth, with each new disaster, another trumpet sounds.

# [Discovery of the fallibility of the divine.]

7/8/2103 - The remnants of a scientific research camp in Antarctica come across a strange monolithic structure in the freezing wastes, inscripted upon it is the first "revelation", presumed to be from God himself. This sparks debate in society over their God's possible fallibility.

# [Even the brightest light will burn out one day.]

8/27/2105 - Suddenly, without any notification, no previous indication, no fanfare, no cataclysmic event, God vanishes. We are alone.

# [Orphans of the father.] 2105-2117

Now that mankind is truly alone, humanity must fend for survival with the very few resources that are available. Demons and lost angels run rampant on the earth, so there is only one thing we must do-

2110 - The plan for constructing a massive spacecraft in order to transport humanity's remnants is developed, it is called "The Exodus", and will take to the stars in 2117.

2117 - Luckily for man, all goes well, and the remnants of mankind takes to the stars and establishes settlements on the inner planets and some on moons of the outer planets.
 
## PART 3: "Let me play among the stars."

# [The Second Exodus]

2117 - With Earth left an irradiated, apocalypse ravaged ruin, The Exodus departs carrying about 500,000 humans, leaving millions on Earth to fend for themselves.

2118 - The first humans reach the inner planets, Mars, Venus, Mercury, etc...

2127 - The last humans to settle the Solar System arrive at moons of the outer planets.

# [Development of new cultures and religions in the planets and moons (as of 2130)]

Mercury - largely uninhabited, mostly focused on industry and mining.

Venus - Cultural center of the inner planets, vast floating cities consisting of inter-connected zeppelins. This cultural paradise leads them to begin the development of a new religion called "Infernism" (more on that later)

Earth - Virtually abandoned, few settlements are located here, with most suffering in a hell on Earth.

Mars - Less culturally focused but more inhabited than Venus, Mars also develops a religion "Deusvultism (crucifiers)", centered around the idea that God has not abandoned Man, and is just testing their fortitude.

Europa - Underwater cities under the ice caps, military capital of the Solar System.

Titan - Home of the most populated city in the Solar System, and location of the Capitol of mankind.

Uranus and beyond - vastly unpopulated, although plans are being made to create a self-sustaining ark that could travel to the farthest reaches of the Solar System and beyond, possibly into deep space and other star systems.

# [The Third (failed) Exodus]

After departing from Titan in 2134 in hopes of finding habitable locations beyond the known Solar System, scans revealed there were none within thousands of light years, dimming hope for humanity's future if disaster were ever to befall them yet again. It is believed everyone on board died (40,000) after losing contact with the ship in 2178.

## PART 4: "SEA OF OFFAL AND ASHES"

# [A cold war] (2135-2174)

This period marked the first true peace in centuries, after decades of despair, things finally seemed like they would soon be going man's way. But war is one of the grim truths of reality.

# [The twins]

Infernism - Infernism, spawned from the zeppelin-cities of Venus, was a religion centered around worshipping a deity called Baphomet. Founded by a supposedly schizophrenic elder trying to rekindle the flames of hope in a world of despair. The Baphomet that the Infernists worship is unrelated to the Baphomet of the old world, and the name is generally understood to be spouted from the founder's mentally ill mind. The Infernists glorify violence, taking heed from a vision the elder had.

Deusvultism - Similarly, Deusvultism also arose from the need for hope in trying times, but is more grounded in reality. The belief holds central the idea that God has not abandoned humanity, but is just testing them to see if humanity is capable of maintaining fortitude in their belief after straying so far from His light. However, many Deusvultists are also heavily fanatical, in stark contrast to their beliefs.

Both religions hold a reputation of being very violent and fanatical, Infernists as part of their belief system, and Deusvultists as the members personalities.

# [Twin Crusades] (2174-2208) !!SECOND CATACLYSM!!

2174 - After tensions between the Infernists and the Deusvultists start running hot, each faction declares holy war on each other.

[MOST HISTORICAL RECORDS HAVE BEEN LOST DURING THIS TIME PERIOD]

2208 - Both sides are exhausted of resources, and constant war and desolation has lead the inner planets to run dry of resources, this is considered to be the second cataclysm of man, following the first, the rapture, 100 years prior.
 
## PART 5: "Hundred year silence"

# [The long night.] (2208-2264)

2208 - The two factions decide to sign a ceasefire after depletion of inner planet resources, motivation, and morale. Each agree to live in isolation and live as their own entities.

2214 - A massive solar flare renders all electronic devices and tools incapable for use in space, trading stops as well as communication between nations, the period of isolation has begun.

Not much else happens during this time period, aside from a few successions of leaders or natural events.

# [Glorified loneliness.] 2264-2301

After the effects of the solar flare wore off, the populace of humanity decided to stay isolated. The reasons behind this were that they believed they should live a peaceful life for the rest of eternity, or at least until the sun died.

[THERE IS NOTHING ELSE IMPORTANT OF NOTE]

## PART 6: "AT HELL'S GATE"

# [Refugees from beyond.]

In the late 2280s, supposedly hyper-evolved humans, descendants of those that arose to paradise but then were abandoned by God arrive in the solar system through rifts in the space-time fabric. They incorporate with the already established factions.

# [The deity's message]

1/1/2301 - With the final curtain call of man, people dying out, nations crumbling, falling, and dying before the universe's eyes, mankind must prepare for one last performance. A sudden signal originating from Pluto is broadcasted across the Solar System. It's message personalized for anyone that receives it, causing each and every human to believe they are "the chosen one", and must go on an odyssey to pluto in order to gain salvation.

1/1/2301 to 2308 - Many die or fail in the struggle to reach Pluto, it is every man for himself, a frenzy unlike any seen in decades. In this struggle's center is ODYSSEUS {placeholder name}, the protagonist of the game's story.

# [The deity's odyssey] 

Odysseus ventures through the planets, encountering original characters, traversing original locations, and finding secrets and lore snippets. At Pluto, he comes face to face with the deity, this deity takes the form of a colossal, almost dream-like serpent towering over mountains. 

[WILL NEED TO THINK MORE ABOUT THE ENDING] !!THIRD CATACLYSM!!"

Rewrite this but it’s set in RDR2, keep the original format.

"The Corpse of King Minos
20
VIEW SOURCE
"If only we knew the suffering that would befall us next..."
This page describes special lore or secret content.
Continue at your own risk!
The Corpse of King Minos

"I used to rule the world... Seas would rise when I gave the word"
Attributes
Appearance
Colossal, parasite-infested humanoid husk with metal bars and barbed wire wrapping around its face
Attack Damage
35 (King's Hand Shockwave)
45 (Punch)
25 (Projectile)
30 (Homing Projectile)
10 (Black Hole, Hard damage override 99)

Health
65 (King's Hand)
160 (Minos)
Support Priority Rank
6
Damage Modifiers
Revolver - 150% (King's Hand only)
Damage to head - 150% (Minos only)
Parries - 500%
Shotgun Parries - 650%

Weight?
Superheavy (Only eye parasites can be targeted)
Susceptible to fall damage
No
Other/Misc
Stationary powerhouse that tests your situational awareness
The Corpse of King Minos is a Supreme Husk and the second unique boss in ULTRAKILL. He is fought in the mission [ 2-4: COURT OF THE CORPSE KING ], though he can be seen in the background of every other level of Lust, getting closer with each mission.


Contents
1	Appearance
2	Combat
2.1	King's Hand
2.2	Phase One Minos
2.3	Phase Two Minos
2.4	Difficulty Changes
3	Rending Apart
4	Terminal Data
5	Lore
6	Trivia
7	Gallery
Appearance
The Corpse of King Minos is a giant dark humanoid with glowing stark-white eyes that project beams of light. He is wrapped from head to toe in barbed wire, which is best seen around his crown and mouth which appear to haphazardly keep the massive bars of metal on his head, back and legs together.

Combat
Though The Corpse of King Minos' attacks are slow and easily predicted, this boss is a test of situational awareness and large-scale arena traversal.

King's Hand
Before the actual encounter, there is a fight with his hand, which simply slams against either wall or the ground to create easily avoidable shockwaves.

The hand has three "phases". During the first phase it can only chain three attacks together, the second phase can do four attacks, and the third phase can do five attacks in a row.

Phase One Minos
When the real battle starts, Minos' corpse will simply throw punches at V1 that can be parried. After a short period of time, Minos' corpse will summon a Black Hole that constantly moves slowly towards V1; though it only deals 10 damage, it will also deal 99 hard damage; if V1 survives the hit, they will be left at 1 HP and unable to heal for several seconds. This hole will persist until the second phase or until it hits V1, requiring it to be constantly evaded.

SnakeEyes
Minos's serpentine eyes revealed in phase two.

Phase Two Minos
At half health, skeletal serpents will burst from Minos' eyes and fire projectiles at the player. Minos' corpse will stop summoning Black Holes, and if one exists it will disappear. The serpents will launch either a large Homing Orb, like those generated by Mindflayers, or a large volley of Hell Orbs, making the sound of a Soldier preparing a volley attack.

After Minos's death, the level exit is revealed in his mouth.

Difficulty Changes
HARMLESS / LENIENT
Minos' corpse will never summon Black Holes.
Minos' parasites will never summon Homing Orbs.
Minos himself moves and attacks much slower. This is especially observable on Harmless.
This also extends to his animations not relating to attacks, such as his phase transition and death. Therefore the exit appears and opens slower on lower difficulties.
VIOLENT
Minos' corpse can still summon Black Holes in his second phase, and existing ones will not disappear.
Rending Apart
Minos' corpse is an incredibly large target, so any weapon will be sure to land hits on him, but the Shotgun and Nailgun are powerful choices even in the hand fight. Shotgun Swapping is very effective at constant damage; despite the spread of the pellets, Minos' corpse is so large that most (if not all) should land. The Overheat Nailgun and the Electric and Screwdriver Railcannon variants are great ways of dealing heavy damage.

Due to him taking 500% more damage from Feedbacker parries, it is advised to parry his melee attacks in order to defeat Minos quickly. While Shotgun Parries are incredibly rewarding and can be performed, it is not advised to do so because of the extremely precise timing to pull it off. Doing either type of parry will also complete the level [ 2-4: COURT OF THE CORPSE KING ]'s challenge. Targeting Minos' hands is advisable when a clear shot can't be made on his body, as this will also allow for easier healing. Orbs shot by serpents can also be parried with good timing, though these deal slightly less damage.

It is possible to stand below one of Minos's hands, jump up and toss 4 Marksman Revolver coins directly up into his hand before shooting at said coins with Electric Railcannon. If you hit a coin while they're all in Minos' hand, you can deal over a quarter of his health in damage.

With precise timing and accuracy, the projectiles the eye parasites are charging can be shot with a piercing hitscan, such as from the Sharpshooter Revolver, Electric Railcannon, or the Alternate Revolver to create an explosion, damaging Minos' corpse and yield the [+INTERRUPTION] style bonus; ironically, this does not prevent the projectile from being fired.

Terminal Data
For more information, see Terminal.

TYPE: SUPREME HUSK

DATA:
Once the great and beloved king of the Lust layer, Minos has now been reduced to a shambling corpse.

Due to his incredible power of will and status as a just ruler in life remembered even millenia[sic] after his death, the manifestation of his soul is the largest Husk to ever have been recorded.

Small traces of the original soul can still be detected in the body, but the corpse itself is animated and controlled entirely by the snakelike Parasites that he once commanded.

Despite once bringing upon the renaissance of the Lust layer, his corpse now only seeks sinners to punish.

STRATEGY:
- Due to his large stature, it can be quite difficult to recover blood from him, but his hands are usually holding on to the walls of the arena, which can be used for refueling.

- Any weapon will work against an enemy this large, but melee and projectile parries make for a quick way to inflict grave damage.

- Although it moves slowly, the Black Hole he summons is extremely dangerous and cannot be destroyed.

Lore
Minos has a great deal of lore surrounding him, first revealed in a book hidden in [ 2-2: DEATH AT 20,000 VOLTS ], which reads:

"...Gabriel struck down Minos, his flesh torn asunder with torrents of crimson pooling at his feet as we all cried out for clarity. 'Justice,' Gabriel decreed to all, with our just ruler writhing in wailing agony, 'The Lord's Will be done.' We watched on in horror as Minos lay broken, now waning, screaming in defiance of God's Will, Gabriel."

This text, combined with the Terminal Data for The Corpse of King Minos, reveals that Minos was a fair ruler of the Lust layer, bringing about a renaissance before being killed by Gabriel. Now, his corpse is animated by snakelike parasites, and it also shows us that the residents of Lust saw Minos as a fair ruler and were horrified to see him killed.

For more lore regarding King Minos, please refer to his character article.

Trivia
The original concept art for the Corpse of King Minos was made by BigRockBMP, and its model was made by Action Dawg with additional rigging by Samuel Bryan.
Minos' corpse is actually fully modeled, although his body is often only partially visible without using Noclip.
While the Corpse of King Minos appears a dark shade of purple, this is mainly contributed to by the bisexual lighting in the Lust layer. His actual color palette is a dark grey, which can be seen in the Terminal.
Though the entrance to Gluttony is in Minos' mouth, Hell is not a single concrete physical space and traversal is described as having a dreamlike inconsistency, and the Gluttony layer is not contained within his corpse. Except when it is.
He is currently the only enemy that offers the [+DOWN TO SIZE] style bonus.
He is also currently the first boss that offers the [+DOUBLE KILL] style bonus from killing a single enemy; however, this only occurs on melee parry deaths. The second is the 1000-THR Defense System.
There is a bug with Minos' corpse where you can freeze his black hole in place. By damaging him below half health as he's pointing his finger to place the black hole down which will cause it to be stuck in place for the entire fight until Minos' corpse is killed (as demonstrated here).
Activating the Disable Enemy Spawns cheat at any point in the Minos' corpse fight will instantly end the battle without playing the death animation. (This does not count as killing the boss.)
King Minos' husk is the only known Husk to keep their eyes (as specified in the Virtue's terminal entry), but still kept them covered with a thorn crown back when he was alive. The same eyes later get destroyed by the parasites controlling his corpse. (What a waste...)
The Corpse of King Minos, Something Wicked, the Leviathan, and the Earthmover are the only enemies that cannot be spawned in the Sandbox. This is because they are built around their levels.
It is rumored that he believes your cells are a bit too far apart, so his punch attack is supposed to fix that for you.
He's so big his hands have graduated from hitbox to hit tesseract.
oh my goodness gracious i can feel the max0r THIS IS THE ONLY WAY IT SHOULD HAVE ENDED
Every single part of the model on The Corpse of King Minos is a hitbox, including the barbed wire around his mouth and crown."
label:
"The Ghost of the Van der Linde Gang's Former Outlaw King
20
VIEW SOURCE
"If only we knew the trials and tribulations that awaited us..."
This page chronicles an epic or secret piece of lore.
Proceed with caution!

The Ghost of the Van der Linde Gang's Former Outlaw King

"In my day, I commanded the frontier... Storms would brew at my beckoning."
Attributes
Appearance
Gargantuan, ghostly figure shrouded in tattered Union and Confederate flags, with ancient firearms and lassos entwined across its visage.
Attack Damage
35 (Outlaw's Fury Ground Slam)
45 (Fist Swing)
25 (Ghostly Bullet)
30 (Seeking Bullet)
10 (Spiritual Vortex, Hard damage override 99)

Health
65 (Outlaw's Fury)
160 (Ex-Outlaw King)
Support Priority Rank
6
Damage Modifiers
Revolver - 150% (Outlaw's Fury only)
Headshot - 150% (Ex-Outlaw King only)
Deflections - 500%
Shotgun Deflections - 650%

Weight?
Immeasurable (Only spectral chains can be targeted)
Susceptible to fall damage
No
Other/Misc
A static behemoth that challenges your adaptability and environmental navigation
The Ghost of the Van der Linde Gang's Former Outlaw King is a Supreme Specter and the second unique boss in WILD HELL. He is encountered in the mission [ 2-4: COURTS OF THE GHOSTLY OUTLAW ], though his ominous presence looms in the shadows of every level within the region, drawing nearer with each story progression.

Contents
1 Appearance
2 Combat
2.1 Outlaw's Fury
2.2 Phase One Ex-Outlaw King
2.3 Phase Two Ex-Outlaw King
2.4 Difficulty Adjustments
3 Disbanding the Spirit
4 Terminal Lore
5 History
6 Fun Facts
7 Gallery
Appearance
The Ghost is an enormous spectral figure with piercing, ethereal white eyes that cast beams of ghostly light. He is enveloped in Civil War-era flags, with his tattered attire barely holding together his spectral guns, ropes, and the skeletal remains of his once proud stature.

Combat
Despite The Ghost's ponderous and telegraphed attacks, this boss is a gauntlet of environmental awareness and mastery over large battlegrounds.

Outlaw's Fury
Before the true clash begins, players first engage with his furious onslaught, which slams into the walls or the earth to create shunning shockwaves.

The fury has three "phases." Initially, it can chain three attacks consecutively, advancing to four, then five relentless barrages.

Phase One Ex-Outlaw King
The real confrontation commences when the Outlaw King's Ghost opts for powerful swings that can be deflected. Shortly after beginning, he summons a Spiritual Vortex moving slowly toward the player; although it inflicts minimal damage, it will also trigger 99 hard damage; surviving players find themselves at 1 HP, momentarily forbidden from healing. The vortex persists until phase two or until impacting the player, necessitating constant evasion.

Phase Two Ex-Outlaw King
Upon reaching half health, ethereal serpents emerge from his eyes, shooting ghostly bullets. The summoning of Spiritual Vortexes ceases. The serpents either unleash a large Seeking Bullet, akin to those produced by Mindflayers, or a barrage of Phantasmal Bullets, echoing an artillery battery prepping a salvo.

Following the Ghost's demise, the way out is revealed within his spectral jaws.

Difficulty Adjustments
HARMLESS / LENIENT
Never summons Spiritual Vortexes.
Parasitic spectral serpents refrain from launching Seeking Bullets.
Movements and attacks substantially slowed. Particularly noticeable on Harmless.
Transitions and demises occur with delayed animations, leading to a slower unveiling and opening at lower challenge levels.
VIOLENT
Can summon Spiritual Vortexes even in the second act, with existing ones enduring.
Disbanding the Spirit
Given his vast size, any armament should hit mark easily, though Shotguns and Dynamite are especially potent even during the initial fury. Shotgun Swapping proves continuously effective; despite pellet spread, the spectral figure's enormity ensures most, if not all, find their target. Overheat-infused Dynamite and Electric Variant Long Rifles present formidable damage options.

Due to his vulnerability to 500% increased damage from precise deflections, it's strategic to deflect his assaults for swift victory. While Shotgun Deflections offer massive rewards, their execution requires utmost timing precision. Performing either deflection also conquers the mission [ 2-4: COURTS OF THE GHOSTLY OUTLAW ]'s challenge. Aiming for the Ghost's chains is prudent for damage focus when direct body shots aren't viable, also facilitating easier healing. The bullets from spectral serpents can be deflected with refined timing, albeit with slightly decreased damage output.

Standing beneath one of the Outlaw's Fury, elevating and aligning 4 Sharpshooter Revolver bullets skyward into the fury before discharging an Electric Variant Long Rifle shot at the bullets can inflict substantial damage if executed with precision.

With accurate timing and targeting, projectiles under formation by the eye serpents can be intercepted with a piercing shot from the Sharpshooter Revolver, Electric Variant Long Rifle, or an Alternate Revolver, creating an explosion harmful to the Ghost's form and achieving the [+INTERRUPTION] style bonus; paradoxically, this does not halt the projectile's launch.

Terminal Lore
For more insights, refer to Terminal.

TYPE: SUPREME SPECTER

DATA:
Once a revered and mighty leader within the Van der Linde gang, he's now a wandering spirit.

His indomitable will and historically noted fairness have allowed his spirit to manifest with unprecedented intensity, marking him the most significant Specter recorded.

Fragments of his old self linger within, though the ghost is fundamentally animated and maneuvered by the spectral chains that once symbolized his authority.

Despite his past era of prosperity, his spirit now relentlessly seeks retribution on those he perceives as sinners.

STRATEGY:
- His grand form complicates blood recovery, yet his hands, often anchored to the arena's confines, serve as refilling conduits.

- Any armament is effective against such a large foe, but melee and projectile deflections offer a fast route to significant harm.

- Despite sluggish motion, the Spiritual Vortex he conjures poses a grave threat and stands indestructible.

History
The ghost holds a concentrated lore, first unveiled in a concealed tome within [ 2-2: DEATH BENEATH THE STARS ], proclaiming:

"...Arthur laid low the king, his body ripped asunder, his blood merging with the soil as our collective pleas for understanding went unheeded. 'Justice,' Arthur proclaimed to all, as our cherished leader writhed and roared in torment, 'This is the decree of the land.' We observed in dismay as he succumbed, reduced to whispers, defying the very essence of justice, Arthur."

This narrative, coupled with the Terminal Lore for The Ghost of the Van der Linde Gang's Former Outlaw King, indicates that he was a just and influential leader of his gang, heralding an era of affluence before being defeated by Arthur. Now, his spirit is propelled by spectral chains, and it is revealed that the gang members regarded him as a fair leader, devastated by his downfall.

For additional lore concerning the Outlaw King, please consult his character documentation.

Fun Facts
The conceptual design for the Ghost of the Van der Linde Gang's Former Outlaw King was crafted by BigRockBMP, with the model realized by Action Dawg and additional rigging by Samuel Bryan.
The Ghost's model is fully detailed, although typically only portions are visible without utilizing Noclip.
Although appearing primarily in shades of gray, this effect is largely due to the dim lighting in the region. His true color scheme is a faded gray, visible in the Terminal.
Though the passage to the next region is through his spectral mouth, the realms aren't physically consistent, often described as transitioning through dreamlike states; the next region does not physically reside within him. Except when it does.
He stands as the sole enemy granting the [+DOWN TO SIZE] style bonus for now.
He is also the inaugural boss offering the [+DOUBLE KILL] style bonus for vanquishing a single foe; achieved solely through melee deflections. The second instance is the 1000-THR Defense Mechanism.
A known glitch with the Ghost allows his Spiritual Vortex to be frozen mid-placement. Triggering this as his health dips below half at the moment he directs the vortex causes it to remain static for the remainder of the encounter until the Ghost is defeated (as showcased here).
Utilizing the Disable Enemy Spawns cheat at any point during the fight with the Ghost immediately concludes the combat without the death animation playing through. (This does not qualify as defeating the boss.)
The Ghost's husk is the only known Specter retaining its eyes (as mentioned in Virtue's terminal entry), yet had them hidden beneath a crown of thorns in life. The sentient chains later obliterate these eyes. (Such a loss...)
The Ghost of the Van der Linde Gang's Former Outlaw King, Something Wicked, the Leviathan, and the Earthmover stand as the only foes not spawnable in Sandbox mode due to their level-specific designs.
It's rumored he considers your molecular structure too loosely arranged, thus his fist attack ostensibly seeks to "correct" this for you.
He's so colossal his extremities have evolved from mere hitboxes to hit hypercubes.
Oh dear heavens I can feel the max0r THIS WAS THE ONE TRUE CONCLUSION
Every aspect of the Ghost's model acts as a hitbox, including the spectral chains and Civil War-era attire."

Rending Apart

Shotgun Swapping is very effective at constant damage; despite the spread of the pellets, Minos' corpse is so large that most (if not all) should land. The Overheat Nailgun and the Electric and Screwdriver Railcannon variants are great ways of dealing heavy damage.

Due to him taking 500% more damage from Feedbacker parries, it is advised to parry his melee attacks in order to defeat Minos quickly. While Shotgun Parries are incredibly rewarding and can be performed, it is not advised to do so because of the extremely precise timing to pull it off. Doing either type of parry will also complete the level [ 2-4: COURT OF THE CORPSE KING ]'s challenge. Targeting Minos' hands is advisable when a clear shot can't be made on his body, as this will also allow for easier healing. Orbs shot by serpents can also be parried with good timing, though these deal slightly less damage.

It is possible to stand below one of Minos's hands, jump up and toss 4 Marksman Revolver coins directly up into his hand before shooting at said coins with Electric Railcannon. If you hit a coin while they're all in Minos' hand, you can deal over a quarter of his health in damage.

With precise timing and accuracy, the projectiles the eye parasites are charging can be shot with a piercing hitscan, such as from the Sharpshooter Revolver, Electric Railcannon, or the Alternate Revolver to create an explosion, damaging Minos' corpse and yield the [+INTERRUPTION] style bonus; ironically, this does not prevent the projectile from being fired.

Terminal Data
For more information, see Terminal.

TYPE: SUPREME HUSK

DATA:
Once the great and beloved king of the Lust layer, Minos has now been reduced to a shambling corpse.

Due to his incredible power of will and status as a just ruler in life remembered even millenia[sic] after his death, the manifestation of his soul is the largest Husk to ever have been recorded.

Small traces of the original soul can still be detected in the body, but the corpse itself is animated and controlled entirely by the snakelike Parasites that he once commanded.

Despite once bringing upon the renaissance of the Lust layer, his corpse now only seeks sinners to punish.

STRATEGY:
- Due to his large stature, it can be quite difficult to recover blood from him, but his hands are usually holding on to the walls of the arena, which can be used for refueling.

- Any weapon will work against an enemy this large, but melee and projectile parries make for a quick way to inflict grave damage.

- Although it moves slowly, the Black Hole he summons is extremely dangerous and cannot be destroyed.

Lore
Minos has a great deal of lore surrounding him, first revealed in a book hidden in [ 2-2: DEATH AT 20,000 VOLTS ], which reads:

"...Gabriel struck down Minos, his flesh torn asunder with torrents of crimson pooling at his feet as we all cried out for clarity. 'Justice,' Gabriel decreed to all, with our just ruler writhing in wailing agony, 'The Lord's Will be done.' We watched on in horror as Minos lay broken, now waning, screaming in defiance of God's Will, Gabriel."

This text, combined with the Terminal Data for The Corpse of King Minos, reveals that Minos was a fair ruler of the Lust layer, bringing about a renaissance before being killed by Gabriel. Now, his corpse is animated by snakelike parasites, and it also shows us that the residents of Lust saw Minos as a fair ruler and were horrified to see him killed.

For more lore regarding King Minos, please refer to his character article.

Trivia
The original concept art for the Corpse of King Minos was made by BigRockBMP, and its model was made by Action Dawg with additional rigging by Samuel Bryan.
Minos' corpse is actually fully modeled, although his body is often only partially visible without using Noclip.
While the Corpse of King Minos appears a dark shade of purple, this is mainly contributed to by the bisexual lighting in the Lust layer. His actual color palette is a dark grey, which can be seen in the Terminal.
Though the entrance to Gluttony is in Minos' mouth, Hell is not a single concrete physical space and traversal is described as having a dreamlike inconsistency, and the Gluttony layer is not contained within his corpse. Except when it is.
He is currently the only enemy that offers the [+DOWN TO SIZE] style bonus.
He is also currently the first boss that offers the [+DOUBLE KILL] style bonus from killing a single enemy; however, this only occurs on melee parry deaths. The second is the 1000-THR Defense System.
There is a bug with Minos' corpse where you can freeze his black hole in place. By damaging him below half health as he's pointing his finger to place the black hole down which will cause it to be stuck in place for the entire fight until Minos' corpse is killed (as demonstrated here).
Activating the Disable Enemy Spawns cheat at any point in the Minos' corpse fight will instantly end the battle without playing the death animation. (This does not count as killing the boss.)
King Minos' husk is the only known Husk to keep their eyes (as specified in the Virtue's terminal entry), but still kept them covered with a thorn crown back when he was alive. The same eyes later get destroyed by the parasites controlling his corpse. (What a waste...)
The Corpse of King Minos, Something Wicked, the Leviathan, and the Earthmover are the only enemies that cannot be spawned in the Sandbox. This is because they are built around their levels.
It is rumored that he believes your cells are a bit too far apart, so his punch attack is supposed to fix that for you.
He's so big his hands have graduated from hitbox to hit tesseract.
oh my goodness gracious i can feel the max0r THIS IS THE ONLY WAY IT SHOULD HAVE ENDED
Every single part of the model on The Corpse of King Minos is a hitbox, including the barbed wire around his mouth and crown."

raw_text: explain in 2000 words Turing's diffusion-driven instability and include the relative equations
label:
Turing's diffusion-driven instability is a mathematic model that describes the formation of patterns in reaction-diffusion systems. The model was first proposed by Alan Turing in 1952 to explain how certain biological organisms such as zebrafish get their stripes, spots, and other distinctive patterns. Turing's model is based on the principle that instability in a homogeneous system can be induced if there is a difference in diffusivity between two or more chemical species. In this article, we will explain the basic concepts of Turing's diffusion-driven instability, including the relevant equations.

Reaction-Diffusion Systems

To understand Turing's model, it is important to first understand the concept of reaction-diffusion systems. These are mathematical models that describe the behavior of chemical reactions in which two or more chemicals interact with each other and diffuse through a medium. The main components of a reaction-diffusion system are the chemical species involved, the rate at which they react with each other, and the rate at which they diffuse through the medium. The dynamics of these systems can be described by a set of partial differential equations.

In a classic reaction-diffusion system, there are two chemical species A and B that react with each other, undergoing a chemical transformation from A to B and vice versa. This can be represented by the following equation:

A + B ⇌ 2B

The rate at which this reaction occurs depends on the concentration of each species and can be described by the following differential equation:

∂A/∂t = k1A – k2AB

∂B/∂t = k2AB – k1B

Where k1 and k2 are rate constants that describe the rates of the forward and reverse reactions, respectively. The concentration of each species changes over time due to both the chemical reaction and diffusion, which can be described by Fick’s law:

∂A/∂t = D1∇2A

∂B/∂t = D2∇2B

Where D1 and D2 are the diffusion constants for species A and B, respectively, and ∇2 is the Laplace operator, which describes the second-order partial derivative of the concentration gradient.

The equations for a reaction-diffusion system can be combined to describe the overall behavior of the system. However, in many cases, the system remains in a homogenous state, meaning that the concentrations of A and B are uniform throughout the medium. This homogenous state is stable, meaning that the system is resistant to small perturbations.

Turing’s Model

Turing’s diffusion-driven instability proposes that a reaction-diffusion system can become unstable if there is a difference in diffusivity between the chemical species present. Specifically, if one species diffuses faster than the other, it can stimulate the formation of spatial patterns in the system. 

Turing’s model uses a simplified system with only two chemical species, X and Y, to describe the phenomenon of pattern formation. Species X and Y can diffuse through a medium with different diffusivity values, D1 and D2, respectively. In the absence of any external perturbations, the system remains in a homogenous state, in which both X and Y are uniformly distributed throughout the medium. However, by introducing small random perturbations, the system can transition into a patterned state.

To understand how this occurs, consider the following equations for the dynamics of the system:

∂X/∂t = F(X, Y) + D1∇2X

∂Y/∂t = G(X, Y) + D2∇2Y

Where F and G are functions that describe the rate at which X and Y react with each other, respectively. These functions can be chosen to describe a wide range of chemical reactions, including autocatalytic and activator-inhibitor reactions.

To visualize how patterns can emerge in this system, imagine that the concentration of species X decreases while the concentration of species Y increases in a certain region of the medium due to a local perturbation. This creates a gradient of X and Y concentrations, which stimulates the diffusion of X from the highly concentrated region to the surrounding low-concentration region. Since X diffuses faster than Y, the concentration of X will decrease more rapidly in the low-concentration region than in the high-concentration region. This creates a positive feedback loop, in which the depletion of X promotes the increase of Y, and vice versa.

In the limit case where D1 is much larger than D2, a spatial pattern can emerge, in which the concentration of X is low in the middle of the pattern and high at the edges, while the concentration of Y is high in the middle and low at the edges. This pattern can repeat itself in space, creating a striated or spotted pattern. 

Mathematical Analysis

To analyze the behavior of Turing's model mathematically, one needs to compute the eigenvalues of the linearized system near the homogeneous steady state. These eigenvalues give insight into the stability of the homogeneous state and the possible formation of a spatial pattern. 

Let us consider the case where D1 >> D2, such that X is much more diffusive than Y. To linearize the system, one can assume that there is a small perturbation around the homogeneous steady-state solution (X*, Y*), where X* and Y* are constants representing the concentration values in the steady state. The perturbation (u, v) can be expressed as follows:

X = X* + u(x, y, t)

Y= Y* + v(x, y, t)

By linearizing the system around the steady-state solution, the partial differential equations can be expressed as a system of linear equations of the form:

∂u/∂t = D1∇2u + f1(v)u

∂v/∂t = D2∇2v + f2(u, v)v

Where f1 and f2 are functions that describe the rate at which the concentrations of X and Y interact with each other. These functions can be derived from the original equations for F(X, Y) and G(X, Y).

To find the eigenvalues of this system, one can assume that u and v are of the form exp(i(kx + ly - wt)), where k and l are the wavenumbers associated with the spatial pattern, and w is the angular frequency associated with the temporal variation of the pattern. Substituting this form into the linearized equations yields:

(w + D1k^2)f1(v)u = D1(k^2 + l^2)u

(w + D2l^2)f2(u, v)v = D2(k^2 + l^2)v

The imaginary part of these equations can be used to calculate the critical value of D1/D2 above which instability occurs. This critical value can be expressed as follows:

D1/D2 > (f2v/f1u)^2

Where f2v and f1u are partial derivatives of the functions f1 and f2 with respect to v and u, respectively. When D1/D2 exceeds this critical value, the homogeneous state becomes unstable, and small perturbations can induce the formation of a spatial pattern.

Applications of Turing's Model

Turing's model has found many applications in a wide range of fields, from biology to material science. In biology, the model has been used to explain how certain animals and plants develop their distinctive patterns, such as zebrafish stripes and leopard spots. In chemistry, Turing's model has been used to explain the formation of nanoparticle patterns on surfaces.

In material science, Turing's model has been used to design novel materials with specific optical or electronic properties. By controlling the reaction and diffusion rates of different chemical species in a reaction-diffusion system, researchers can create complex patterns with useful properties. For example, colloidal crystals and photonic structures can be formed by controlling the self-assembly of nanoparticles using Turing's principles.

Conclusion

Turing's diffusion-driven instability is a powerful mathematical model that describes the formation of spatial patterns in reaction-diffusion systems. The model is based on the principle that instability can be induced in a homogeneous system if there is a difference in diffusivity between two or more chemical species. By studying the reaction and diffusion rates of chemical species, researchers can design materials with specific properties, and biologists can explain the formation of patterns in living organisms. Turing's model has found applications in many fields and continues to be a source of inspiration for researchers interested in pattern formation and self-assembly in complex systems.

raw_text: Create a script for 5th grade math students, providing  15 real life examples for 5th grade math students showing why using the formula to find the area is important.  include explanations throughout showing students how to solve these area problems step by step.  Provide a question for students to answer the example before giving the answer to the example.  Cover the objective MA.5.GR.2.1 - Find the perimeter and area of a rectangle with fractional or decimal side lengths using visual models and formulas through the examples
label:
**Introduction:**
Today, we are going to learn why it is important to use the formula to find the area. We will explore various real-life examples that require us to calculate the area step by step. Our learning objective for this lesson is MA.5.GR.2.1 - finding the perimeter and area of a rectangle with fractional or decimal side lengths using visual models and formulas. Let's dive into our examples!

Example 1:
Imagine you have a rectangular garden with a length of 10 feet and a width of 5 feet. What is the area of the garden?
Question: What is the area of the garden?
(a) 10 square feet
(b) 25 square feet
(c) 50 square feet
(d) 100 square feet

Explanation: To find the area of a rectangle, we multiply its length by its width. Here, the length is 10 feet and the width is 5 feet. So, the area of the garden is 10 feet × 5 feet = 50 square feet. Therefore, the correct answer is (c) 50 square feet.

Example 2:
You want to buy a rectangular rug for your room. The rug has a length of 6 feet and a width of 4 feet. How much space will the rug cover on the floor?
Question: How much space will the rug cover on the floor?
(a) 12 square feet
(b) 24 square feet
(c) 36 square feet
(d) 48 square feet

Explanation: To find the area, we multiply the length by the width. In this case, the length of the rug is 6 feet and the width is 4 feet. So, the area covered by the rug on the floor is 6 feet × 4 feet = 24 square feet. The correct answer is (b) 24 square feet.

Example 3:
You are baking a rectangular cake with a length of 12 inches and a width of 8 inches. How much frosting do you need to cover the top of the cake?
Question: How much frosting do you need to cover the top of the cake?
(a) 16 square inches
(b) 32 square inches
(c) 48 square inches
(d) 96 square inches

Explanation: The area of the cake's top surface represents the amount of frosting needed. We multiply the length (12 inches) by the width (8 inches). The area of the top of the cake is 12 inches × 8 inches = 96 square inches. The correct answer is (d) 96 square inches.

Example 4:
You have a rectangular swimming pool with a length of 20 meters and a width of 10 meters. How much water can the pool hold?
Question: How much water can the pool hold?
(a) 200 square meters
(b) 400 square meters
(c) 2,000 square meters
(d) 4,000 square meters

Explanation: The area of the base of the pool represents its capacity. To find the area, we multiply the length (20 meters) by the width (10 meters). The pool can hold 20 meters × 10 meters = 200 square meters of water. The correct answer is (a) 200 square meters.

Example 5:
You are planting a rectangular garden with a length of 16 feet and a width of 12 feet. How much soil do you need to fill the garden bed?
Question: How much soil do you need to fill the garden bed?
(a) 28 square feet
(b) 144 square feet
(c) 192 square feet
(d) 288 square feet

Explanation: The area of the garden bed represents the amount of soil needed. We multiply the length (16 feet) by the width (12 feet) to find the area. The garden bed requires 16 feet × 12 feet = 192 square feet of soil. The correct answer is (c) 192 square feet.

Example 6:
You are repainting a rectangular wall with a length of 8 feet and a width of 10 feet. How much paint do you need to cover the entire wall?
Question: How much paint do you need to cover the entire wall?
(a) 18 square feet
(b) 80 square feet
(c) 64 square feet
(d) 800 square feet

Explanation: The area of the wall represents the amount of paint needed. Multiply the length (8 feet) by the width (10 feet) to find the area. The wall requires 8 feet × 10 feet = 80 square feet of paint. The correct answer is (b) 80 square feet.

Example 7:
You are laying new carpet in your room, which has a length of 14 feet and a width of 9 feet. How much carpet do you need to cover the entire floor?
Question: How much carpet do you need to cover the entire floor?
(a) 63 square feet
(b) 90 square feet
(c) 126 square feet
(d) 144 square feet

Explanation: The area of the floor represents the amount of carpet needed. Multiply the length (14 feet) by the width (9 feet) to find the area. The room requires 14 feet × 9 feet = 126 square feet of carpet. The correct answer is (c) 126 square feet.

Example 8:
You are wrapping a rectangular gift box with a length of 18 inches and a width of 6 inches. How much wrapping paper do you need to cover the entire box?
Question: How much wrapping paper do you need to cover the entire box?
(a) 42 square inches
(b) 72 square inches
(c) 108 square inches
(d) 324 square inches

Explanation: The area of the gift box represents the amount of wrapping paper needed. Multiply the length (18 inches) by the width (6 inches) to find the area. The box requires 18 inches × 6 inches = 108 square inches of wrapping paper. The correct answer is (c) 108 square inches.

Example 9:
You are building a rectangular fence around your garden, which is 15 feet long and 7 feet wide. How much material do you need for the fence?
Question: How much material do you need for the fence?
(a) 22 feet
(b) 55 feet
(c) 90 feet
(d) 210 feet

Explanation: The perimeter of the garden (the sum of all sides) represents the amount of fence material needed. We can find the perimeter by adding twice the length to twice the width (2 × 15 feet + 2 × 7 feet). The fence requires 2 × 15 feet + 2 × 7 feet = 44 feet of material. The correct answer is (a) 44 feet.

Example 10:
You want to build a rectangular patio in your backyard. The patio will be 24 feet long and 10 feet wide. How much paving material do you need?
Question: How much paving material do you need?
(a) 68 feet
(b) 240 feet
(c) 340 feet
(d) 480 feet

Explanation: The perimeter of the patio represents the amount of paving material needed. Add twice the length to twice the width (2 × 24 feet + 2 × 10 feet). The patio requires 2 × 24 feet + 2 × 10 feet = 68 feet of paving material. The correct answer is (a) 68 feet.

Example 11:
You have a rectangular pool with a length of 18 meters and a width of 12 meters. How much fencing do you need to enclose the pool?
Question: How much fencing do you need to enclose the pool?
(a) 24 meters
(b) 60 meters
(c) 84 meters
(d) 120 meters

Explanation: The perimeter of the pool represents the amount of fencing needed. Add twice the length to twice the width (2 × 18 meters + 2 × 12 meters). The pool requires 2 × 18 meters + 2 × 12 meters = 60 meters of fencing. The correct answer is (b) 60 meters.

Example 12:
You are laying tiles on a rectangular kitchen floor that is 10 feet long and 6 feet wide. How many tiles do you need?
Question: How many tiles do you need?
(a) 15
(b) 36
(c) 60
(d) 100

Explanation: The area of the floor represents the number of tiles needed. Multiply the length (10 feet) by the width (6 feet) to find the area. The kitchen floor requires 10 feet × 6 feet = 60 tiles. The correct answer is (c) 60 tiles.

Example 13:
You are building a rectangular bookshelf with a length of 5 feet and a width of 2 feet. How much paint do you need to cover the entire bookshelf?
Question: How much paint do you need to cover the entire bookshelf?
(a) 5 square feet
(b) 10 square feet
(c) 15 square feet
(d) 20 square feet

Explanation: The area of the bookshelf represents the amount of paint needed. Multiply the length (5 feet) by the width (2 feet) to find the area. The bookshelf requires 5 feet × 2 feet = 10 square feet of paint. The correct answer is (b) 10 square feet.

Example 14:
You're planning to install a rectangular rug in your living room. The rug measures 9 feet in length and 6 feet in width. How much space will the rug cover?
Question: How much space will the rug cover?
(a) 5 square feet
(b) 9 square feet
(c) 15 square feet
(d) 54 square feet

Explanation: The area of the rug represents the space it will cover. Multiply the length (9 feet) by the width (6 feet) to find the area. The rug will cover 9 feet × 6 feet = 54 square feet of space. The correct answer is (d) 54 square feet.

Example 15:
You're building a rectangular sandbox with a length of 7 feet and a width of 4 feet. How much sand will you need to fill the sandbox?
Question: How much sand will you need to fill the sandbox?
(a) 9 square feet
(b) 11 square feet
(c) 21 square feet
(d) 28 square feet

Explanation: The area of the sandbox represents the amount of sand needed. Multiply the length (7 feet) by the width (4 feet) to find the area. The sandbox will require 7 feet × 4 feet = 28 square feet of sand. The correct answer is (d) 28 square feet.

raw_text: Make another 22 MCQs that are more programming specific and not just about general text processing.
label:
1. Which command in Vim allows you to compile the current C program?
a) :make
b) :compile
c) :gcc
Answer: a) :make
Explanation: The ":make" command in Vim runs the Makefile associated with the current C program to compile it.

2. How can you toggle between the header and implementation file in Vim when editing a C/C++ source file?
a) :split
b) :edit
c) :hfile
Answer: b) :edit
Explanation: In Vim, typing ":edit" toggles between the header and implementation file while editing a C/C++ source file.

3. What Vim feature can be used to automatically insert closing parentheses, brackets, and quotes in programming files?
a) AutoComplete
b) AutoClose
c) AutoInsert
Answer: b) AutoClose
Explanation: Vim's AutoClose feature automatically inserts closing parentheses, brackets, and quotes in programming files.

4. How can you navigate to the definition of a function or variable in Vim?
a) :goto
b) :jump
c) Ctrl+] or :tag
Answer: c) Ctrl+] or :tag
Explanation: Pressing Ctrl+] or typing ":tag" in Vim takes you to the definition of a function or variable.

5. How can you use Vim to run a Python script and view the output?
a) :run
b) :exec
c) :!python %
Answer: c) :!python %
Explanation: Typing ":!python %" in Vim runs the current Python script and displays the output.

6. Which command in Vim enables code folding for easier navigation?
a) :folding
b) :fold
c) :set foldmethod=syntax
Answer: c) :set foldmethod=syntax
Explanation: The command ":set foldmethod=syntax" in Vim enables code folding based on syntax, allowing for easier navigation.

7. How can you comment/uncomment multiple lines of code in Vim?
a) :comment
b) ://comment
c) :normal I//
Answer: c) :normal I//
Explanation: Typing ":normal I//" in Vim allows you to comment/uncomment multiple lines of code by inserting "//" at the beginning.

8. Which Vim command displays function prototypes and their documentation within a split window?
a) :help
b) :preview
c) :copen
Answer: c) :copen
Explanation: The ":copen" command in Vim opens a split window displaying function prototypes and their documentation.

9. How can you automatically format (indent) code in Vim?
a) :autoformat
b) :indent
c) =G (in Visual Line mode)
Answer: c) =G (in Visual Line mode)
Explanation: Pressing "=G" in Visual Line mode indents (formats) the code according to the current indent settings.

10. What does the "+y" command do in Vim?
a) Copies the current line to the system clipboard
b) Appends the current line to the system clipboard
c) Yanks the current line to a Vim register
Answer: a) Copies the current line to the system clipboard
Explanation: Typing "+y in Vim copies the current line to the system clipboard.

11. How can you insert a blank line below the current line in Vim?
a) :append
b) o
c) :blank
Answer: b) o
Explanation: Pressing "o" in Vim enters Insert mode and opens a new line below the current line.

12. Which command in Vim allows you to rename a variable throughout the entire file?
a) :rename
b) :substitute
c) :change
Answer: b) :substitute
Explanation: The ":substitute" command in Vim allows you to rename a variable by replacing all occurrences throughout the file.

13. How can you highlight all occurrences of a word within a file in Vim?
a) :highlight
b) :search
c) :match
Answer: c) :match
Explanation: Typing ":match Search /word/" in Vim highlights all occurrences of "word" within the file.

14. What does the command ":vsplit filename" do in Vim?
a) Splits the editor window horizontally and opens "filename"
b) Splits the editor window vertically and opens "filename"
c) Opens a new buffer with the contents of "filename"
Answer: b) Splits the editor window vertically and opens "filename"
Explanation: The ":vsplit filename" command in Vim splits the editor window vertically and opens "filename" in the new split.

15. How can you replace all occurrences of a word in the entire file using the command-line in Vim?
a) %s/word/new_word
b) :replace word new_word %
c) :global/word/new_word
Answer: a) %s/word/new_word
Explanation: The command "%s/word/new_word" in Vim replaces all occurrences of "word" with "new_word" throughout the entire file.

16. Which command in Vim allows you to record a series of actions and play them back later?
a) :record
b) :macro
c) q followed by a register
Answer: c) q followed by a register
Explanation: Pressing "q" followed by a register (e.g., q followed by a) in Vim allows you to record a series of actions.

17. How can you change the case of a word in Vim from lowercase to uppercase?
a) :casemodify upper
b) ~
c) guu
Answer: b) ~
Explanation: Pressing "~" in Vim changes the case of the character under the cursor. Repeating it on a word will change the case of the entire word.

18. What does the command ":tabnew" do in Vim?
a) Opens a new vertical split tab
b) Opens a new horizontal split tab
c) Opens a completely new tab
Answer: c) Opens a completely new tab
Explanation: Typing ":tabnew" in Vim opens a completely new tab, allowing you to work on a different file.

19. How can you insert the current date and time at the current cursor position in Vim?
a) :date
b) :time
c) :r!date
Answer: c) :r!date
Explanation: Typing ":r!date" in Vim inserts the current date and time at the current cursor position.

20. Which Vim command allows you to move lines (or selections) up or down?
a) :swap
b) :move
c) :shift
Answer: b) :move
Explanation: The ":move" command in Vim allows you to move lines (or selections) up or down within the file.

21. How can you execute a shell command and insert its output into the buffer in Vim?
a) :exec
b) :shell
c) :read !command
Answer: c) :read !command
Explanation: Typing ":read !command" in Vim executes the shell command and inserts its output into the buffer.

22. What does the ">>" command do in Vim?
a) Indents the current line or selected block to the right
b) Duplicates the current line or selected block
c) Moves the cursor to the beginning of the next line
Answer: a) Indents the current line or selected block to the right
Explanation: In Vim, typing ">>" indents the current line or selected block to the right.

raw_text:
1.

List various types of Collision Resolution methods in Hashing.

Write down the complexity of Insertion sort and Merge sort.

2.

Interpret the representation of graphs in memory.

3.

Compare and Contrast Binary Search Trees and Heaps.

4.

Sectics (2 questions × 4 marks - 8 marks

Apply the procedure of Selection sort on the followingray: 30,20,40,70,10 and outline the steps of an algorithm.

Explain the various rotations of AVL trees in detail.

Classify the types of Linked list and explain the algorithm of Insertion in Doubly Linked list with the help of suitable example.

Section-C (1 question × 8 marks = 8 mark

Examine the procedure of Depth First Search traversal and explain an example of directed graph.

Elaborate the algorithm for Inorder traversal in Binary Tree with the help of an example.
label:
### Section-A

1. **Collision Resolution Methods in Hashing:**

   - **Linear Probing:** When a collision occurs, linear probing searches for the next available slot in a linear sequence.
   - **Quadratic Probing:** Similar to linear probing but uses a quadratic function to find the next slot, reducing clustering.
   - **Double Hashing:** Uses a second hash function to determine the interval between probes.
   - **Separate Chaining:** Each slot in the hash table points to a linked list (or another data structure) that holds all elements hashing to the same index.
   - **Coalesced Chaining:** A combination of separate chaining and open addressing.
   - **Cuckoo Hashing:** Uses two hash functions and positions each key in one of two possible positions, moving other keys as necessary.

**Complexity of Sorting Algorithms:**

- **Insertion Sort:** Average and worst-case time complexity is O(n^2), where n is the number of elements. Space complexity is O(1).
- **Merge Sort:** Average and worst-case time complexity is O(n log n), where n is the number of elements. Space complexity is O(n).

### Section-B

2. **Representation of Graphs in Memory:**

   - **Adjacency Matrix:** A 2D array where the element at `matrix[i][j]` is 1 (or the weight of the edge) if there is an edge from vertex i to vertex j, otherwise 0.
   - **Adjacency List:** An array of lists. The index of the array represents a vertex and each element in its list represents the other vertices that form an edge with the vertex.
   - **Edge List:** A list of all edges, where each edge is represented as a pair (or a tuple if weighted) of vertices.

3. **Binary Search Trees (BSTs) vs. Heaps:**

   - **Structure:** BSTs are ordered trees where each node has at most two children, and for any node, the left child's value is less than the node's value, and the right child's value is greater. Heaps are complete binary trees where each node's value is greater than or equal to (max-heap) or less than or equal to (min-heap) the values of its children.
   - **Operations:** In BSTs, search, insertion, and deletion operations are O(log n) on average, whereas in a heap, the main operations are insert and extract-min/max, which are also O(log n).
   - **Usage:** BSTs are used for ordered data storage, while heaps are used for priority queues and heap sort.

4. **Selection Sort on Array: 30, 20, 40, 70, 10**

   - Initial array: [30, 20, 40, 70, 10]
   - Find the minimum element in the array and swap it with the first element.
   - [**10**, 20, 40, 70, 30] (10 is now in the correct position)
   - Repeat the process for the remaining array (excluding the sorted part).
   - [10, **20**, 40, 70, 30] (20 is now in the correct position)
   - Continue this process.
   - [10, 20, **30**, 70, 40]
   - [10, 20, 30, **40**, 70]
   - The array is now sorted.

**Rotations in AVL Trees:**

   - **Single Right Rotation (LL Rotation):** Used when a left-left case occurs, i.e., the left subtree of the left child is causing the imbalance.
   - **Single Left Rotation (RR Rotation):** Used when a right-right case occurs, i.e., the right subtree of the right child is causing the imbalance.
   - **Left-Right Rotation (LR Rotation):** A double rotation, first a left rotation on the left child, followed by a right rotation on the node.
   - **Right-Left Rotation (RL Rotation):** A double rotation, first a right rotation on the right child, followed by a left rotation on the node.

**Types of Linked Lists:**

   - **Singly Linked List:** Each node points to the next node and the last node points to null.
   - **Doubly Linked List:** Each node has two pointers, one to the next node and one to the previous node.
   - **Circular Linked List:** Similar to singly or doubly linked lists, but the last node points back to the first node.

**Insertion in a Doubly Linked List:**

   - Create a new node with the given value.
   - If the list is empty, set the head to the new node.
   - If inserting at the beginning, update the head and adjust pointers.
   - If inserting after a given node, adjust the next and previous pointers of the new node and the adjacent nodes.

### Section-C

5. **Depth First Search (DFS) Traversal:**

   - DFS explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking.
   - Use a stack (explicit or via recursion) to keep track of the vertices.
   - Mark each vertex visited to avoid cycles.
   - Example: Given a directed graph, start at a vertex, visit an adjacent unvisited vertex, mark it as visited, and recurse. Continue until all vertices are visited.

6. **Inorder Traversal in Binary Tree:**

   - Inorder traversal visits nodes in the left subtree, then the root node, and finally the right subtree.
   - It can be done recursively or iteratively with a stack.
   - Example: Given a binary tree, perform the following steps:
     - Traverse the left subtree by recursively calling the inorder function.
     - Visit the root node (e.g., print the node's value).
     - Traverse the right subtree by recursively calling the inorder function.
   - This traversal results in the nodes being visited in ascending order for BSTs.
